text: so the material and offshoring developed
from a mutual recognition by the Big E

team there was a gap in the curriculum
that we were not covering in the

offshoring we also had to come up with
some assessment of how big a phenomenon
is this there are many assessments out
there we stumbled upon particularly a
very interesting paper by Alan Blinder
Princeton economist in which he went
through eight hundred occupations in the
US economy and rated each one on his
potential offshore ability we realized
that we could simply make that an
exhibit in the case but that would have
very little impact and we got the idea
that perhaps we could actually have much
greater impact in the students
themselves recreated Ellen binders
exercise through an online computer
application and that's what we did we
had a technology that was provided by
etg and allowed us to collectively
across the cost of 2009 recreate the the
research the exercise was as follows
that each to learning team and their 152
of them each learning team would receive
information online about 20 occupations
and they would be asked to respond to
each occupation in two ways first they
would assess on a particular scale the
offshore ability of that occupation and
they'd received lots of information
online about the occupation so that they
can make that assessment in a
intelligent way for those jobs they
rated as potentially quite offshore bow
they were then asked which country will
this job potentially go to and they had
a list of candidate countries that were
countries they'd studied or would study
in biggie once the student learning
teams had made those assessments within
any were able to compile across the
entire class some data on the offshore
ability of each occupation one thing the
students were able seemed very readily
from looking at their individual team

assessments across the the class
was that the jobs were being off short
or they're likely to be off horrible
were not simply low-end manufacturing
jobs they weren't just call center jobs
they were jobs that our students would
be interested in and I think for many of

recognize that it's not simply someone
else whose jobs at stake makes this a
much more personal experience now the
